definition: A reason for being; the thing that makes life feel worth living.
usage_notes: Often used for a personal sense of purpose that blends joy, mission, and contribution.
example_native: 彼は家族が生き甲斐だ。

definition: An aesthetic that finds beauty in impermanence, imperfection, and simplicity.
usage_notes: Guides art, craft, tea ceremony, design.

definition: The act of acquiring reading materials and letting them pile up, unread.
example_native: 積ん読の本が増えている。

definition: Sunlight filtering through leaves of trees.
example_native: 木漏れ日が気持ちいい。

definition: A bittersweet awareness of impermanence; the gentle sadness of transience.
example_native: 桜は物の哀れを感じさせる。
example_gloss: Cherry blossoms evoke mono no aware.

definition: A profound grace and subtle mystery beyond what can be articulated.
A presumption of indulgent dependence within close relationships.
Public façade vs. one’s true feelings/opinions.
example_native: 建前と本音のギャップ
example_gloss: The gap between tatemae and honne.

definition: Death from overwork.
‘Forest bathing’: restorative immersion in forests.
Thoughtful, wholehearted hospitality anticipating guests’ needs.
A sense of regret over waste; respect for resources.
example_native: 食べ物を捨てるのは勿体無い。

definition: Initially cold/hostile then warm/affectionate.
Art of repairing broken pottery with lacquer and gold, embracing flaws.
A traditional system for harmonizing individuals with their environment.
Networks of relationships and reciprocal obligations.
A fated affinity that brings people together.
Human feelings; the moral economy of favors and obligations.
Reputation and dignity in social contexts; ‘face’.
Vital life energy or breath underlying phenomena.
To ‘eat bitterness’: endure hardship with resilience.
Lively, bustling atmosphere (pleasantly so).
‘Involution’: spiraling competition without productive gains.
An exhortation to keep going; you’ve got this!
The subtle art of reading the room and others’ feelings.
A deep, collective sadness and regret, mixed with hope and resilience.
A warm, enduring affection/bond formed over time.
A ‘hurry-hurry’ mindset valuing speed and efficiency.
Pleasure derived from another’s misfortune.
Secondhand embarrassment felt for someone else.
Weight gained from emotional overeating.
World-weariness; sorrow about the world’s state.
Panic about diminishing opportunities as time passes.
The ability to sit and persist at a task for a long time.
The perfect retort that comes to mind after the moment has passed.
The spirit or mood of a particular period of history.
A deep, nostalgic longing for something or someone absent yet cherished.
The act of tenderly running fingers through someone’s hair.
Improvisational resourcefulness to ‘unstick’ a tricky situation.
Playful cunning/roguish streetwise charm.
The time spent lingering at the table after a meal, chatting.
To use or wear something for the first time.
usage_notes: Also for premieres of films, etc.
example_gloss: I’m going to wear the shoes for the first time.

definition: Secondhand embarrassment felt on someone else’s behalf.
A mysterious power of art (esp. flamenco) to deeply move.
The environmental and cultural factors giving a product its character.
The disorientation (often pleasant) of being out of one’s familiar environment.
A stroller-observer of the city, savoring its scenes.
A cheerful enjoyment of life; zest for living.
example_native: Sa joie de vivre est contagieuse.
example_gloss: Her joie de vivre is contagious.

definition: A sudden shiver of excitement or fear, often from art/music.
example_gloss: A frisson runs through the hall.

definition: The French model of state secularism governing religion’s role in public life.
The witty remark thought of too late, on the stairs.
Studied carelessness; effortless grace hiding effort.
Drowsiness after a big meal.
An evening stroll, primarily for socializing and seeing others.
Cultivating a good public impression through appearance and conduct.
The tendency to look for hidden motives behind events; ‘behindology’.
A mood of comfortable, convivial coziness with friends and simple pleasures.
Warm coziness/pleasant time, often with others.
In balance; just the right amount—neither too much nor too little.
To wake up early to go out and hear the first birdsong.
Stoic determination, grit, and courage in the face of adversity.
Getting drunk alone at home in your underwear (no intention to go out).
A warm, friendly, convivial atmosphere with others.
To walk in windy weather (esp. by the sea) to clear one’s head.
example_gloss: A nice uitwaaien by the sea.

definition: The fun/pleasure experienced in anticipating something enjoyable.
A homesickness tinged with grief and longing for a home that may never have been.
A social gathering with folk music, dancing, and storytelling.
Dull, damp, and chilly weather; bleak and grey.
Good times, lively conversation, fun; also ‘what’s the news/gossip?’.
example_gloss: It was great craic last night.

definition: ‘Window-weather’: looks nice from inside, but unpleasant outside.
A deep spiritual anguish; vague longing with no specific cause (per Nabokov).
Banality and vulgarity masquerading as refinement; spiritual crassness.
A state of torment caused by sudden insight into one’s own misery (per Kundera).
To scheme/contrive resourcefully around constraints (not necessarily honest).
Bittersweet longing for someone/something absent; akin to saudade.
To do something with soul, creativity, and love; to put part of yourself into it.
A joyful, high-spirited mood that spurs celebration or creativity.
Love of strangers; generous hospitality to guests.
A communal melancholy or spiritual sadness (often associated with Istanbul).
A pleasant state of idle, content relaxation.
The phosphorescent glow of bioluminescent sea at night.
Ecstatic musical enchantment; being carried away by music.
A sense of exile/estrangement and longing for home.
Using connections/influence to get things done.

language: Persian (via Hebrew script here for clarity?)
definition: Elaborate ritual politeness and deference shaping offers/refusals.
example_gloss: Don’t do taarof (no need for ceremony).

definition: Elaborate ritual politeness and deference shaping offers/refusals.
example_gloss: Don’t do taarof (no need for ceremony).

definition: Unselfish, genuine delight in someone else’s success.
An emphatic ‘precisely/ironically/contrary to expectation’.
Frugal, improvisational workaround under constraints.
Honor/respect/social standing to be upheld.
A sacred glimpse/encounter with a deity or holy person.
example_gloss: We had darshan at the temple.

definition: Selfless service performed without expectation of reward.
Worth the money; value extracted fully (esp. for entertainment).
Mutual cooperation/community self-help.
A joke so poorly told and unfunny that one can’t help but laugh.
Mass homecoming to one’s hometown (esp. during Eid).
A deep ‘debt of inner gratitude’ to someone who helped you.
example_native: May utang na loob ako sa kanya.
example_gloss: I have utang na loob to her.

definition: A fluttery thrill felt during romantic moments.
The irresistible urge to squeeze/squish something because it’s cute.
Silent sulking or withdrawing affection without open confrontation.
Considerate restraint to avoid imposing on others.
example_native: เกรงใจมากเลย
example_gloss: I really don’t want to impose.

definition: The value of fun/playfulness in daily life.
example_native: ให้มันสนุกหน่อย

definition: A state of ease/relaxation/comfort; ‘all good’.
Love, peace, compassion; also a greeting/farewell embodying that spirit.
Righteousness, balance, and moral correctness.
Extended family/community who support each other.
Sacredness/forbiddenness with spiritual sanctions (source of English ‘taboo’).
Spiritual power/authority/prestige emanating from persons or objects.
Extended family/community unit central to social life.
Guardianship/stewardship of the environment and resources.
‘I am because we are’: a philosophy of communal personhood and mutual care.
example_gloss: A person is a person through other persons.

definition: Go back and fetch it: return to the past to retrieve what’s valuable for the future.
The power to make things happen through word/authority/spiritual force.
Reciprocal labor exchange and mutual aid within communities.
A preference for foreign things over native ones, seen as disloyal.
Audacious nerve; boldness that can be admirable or outrageous.
To feel delighted pride, esp. in one’s children/community.
To drag/carry something (or oneself) laboriously.
example_native: I had to schlep the boxes.

definition: The feeling of anticipation that makes you go outside to check if someone is coming.
A look shared by two people each hoping the other will act first.
Prozvonitis when you call but only let it ring once so that the other person calls back without so you save money or minutes.

Pronounced [ah-bites-gleh-the], this compound word is make up of arbejde meaning ‘work’ and glæde meaning ‘happiness’ so arbejdsglæde literally means ‘job joy’, ‘job satisfaction’ or ‘happiness at work.’ It’s the heightened sense of happiness, fulfilment, and satisfaction you get from having a great job.  This untranslatable word also exists in the other Nordic languages, including Swedish, Norwegian, Finnish and Icelandic.
A person who throws water on hot rocks to make steam in a sauna.
A severe absence of enthusiasm to do something. When you just don’t have enough strength, will power to do something or can’t be bothered.

Kaamos is more than just Polar Night when there are 24 consecutive hours of darkness,  kaamos describes the longing for sunshine, and a feeling of depression and lack of motivation and enthusiasm. It signifies long dark days and bad weather, no social life, and a lack of inspiration.
A trunk of a tree that has submerged to the bottom of a lake.
Pronounced [talk-uh] is a Finnish collective noun for a large herd of reindeer. It is said that there are as many reindeer as there are people in Finland.
A sense of panic associated with a huge defeat. The word Bérézina is used in the French idom

A bricoleur is a handyman who uses whatever materials he can get his hands on to create a construction (or bricolage). Think of the well-known term Bric-à-brac –  miscellaneous objects and ornaments of little value. The closest equivalent in English would be something like a DIY-er.
Literally ‘stairwell wit’, l’esprit de l’escalier is the feeling that you’ve got the perfect comeback, but you think of it too late. Similar to the German, treppenwitz, mentioned earlier.
German is full of hilarious phrases

The urgent need to explain something, either yourself or the situation. It can also mean to struggle explaining something. Erklärungsnot is made up of the German words Erklärung (‘explanation’) and not (in this case, can be translated as ‘need.’)
Fachidiot, literally it means ‘subject-idiot’. A fachidiot is a person with expert knowledge in their own field and are well-accomplished but are clueless when it comes to anything outside that area.

The love and pleasure one feels from simply driving around. The German compound word fahrvergnügen comes from fahren (‘to drive’) and‎ vergnügen (‘pleasure’). This term was popularised in the USA by Volkswagen advertisements in the 1990s.
Fernweh is one of my favourite travel words that describe wanderlust perfectly
This represents a temporary state of sloppiness, usually elicited by a person’s nagging. This often means that a person is flustered to the point of incompetence.

Handschuhschneeballwerfer is German slang for ‘coward’. It literally means, ‘someone who wears gloves to throw snowballs’. In other words, a cowardly person who criticises and abuses something from a safe distance.

Lebensmüde is a German compound noun made up of the words leben (life) and müde (tired), and literally means ‘life tired’. It describes the feeling of being tired or weary of life. Its closest English equivalents are probably world-weary, depressed, fed up, restless and dissatisfied.
A street that is so overcrowded and rammed with street signs, that you’re more prone to getting lost rather than finding your way.
Something that was meant to be an improvement, but actually makes things worse.
Literally, ‘schnapps idea’, is a plan so ridiculous you must have been drunk when you thought it up.

The feeling of being alone in the woods. Derived from two German words ‘wald,’ meaning forest, and ‘einsamkeit,’ meaning loneliness, it refers to a connectedness with nature and the peace experienced in that moment.
Weichei is a German slang term which used to refer to a cowardly person. Literally meaning ‘a soft egg’, the closest English equivalent would be ‘wimp’.

Filotimo is almost impossible to translate but can be summed up as ‘love of honour’. It describes a person who understands the responsibility to themselves, as a human, being to always do the right thing and with honour. Even if their wealth, safety, freedom, or even life is at peril. No matter what, this person will do the honourable thing, regardless of the consequence.
In Greek culture, a parea is when a group of friends gather to share life experiences, philosophies, values, and ideas.
Psithurism is the rustling sound of leaves in the wind. It comes from the Greek psithuros, meaning ‘whispering, slanderous.’
The act of scratching your head in an attempt to remember something you’ve forgotten.
A nickname for your spouse or better half who is constantly nagging. It literally means an ‘Domestic Dragon’
Being unwilling to spend time or money on a particular thing, even though you can afford it.
A lighthearted prank where you trick someone by tapping their opposite shoulder from where you’re standing in order to fool them. That’s mencolek!
A batch of Easter eggs.

Literally reheated cabbage, this is essentially an attempt to reheat an old romance. In other parts of Italy, ‘minestra riscaldata‘ or ‘zuppa riscaldata’, meaning reheated soup, is used to describe the same sentiment.
Culaccino refers to the dregs in a glass but also the residue or water ring left on a surface by a moist, cold glass or other small container. In Italian, ‘culo‘ means bottom.
A woman devoted to caring for and feeding stray or domestic cats. A more extreme version of a cat lover.
To finish up the contents of your plate, especially the sauce, with a piece of bread.
Pronounced [aah-gey-oh-toh-ree], Age-otori is a beautiful Japanese word that perfectly sums up a disaster haircut that makes you look worse than before.

This is used to refer to an act that someone does for you, even though you didn’t want to have them do it and tried to avoid having them do. They might have gone ahead,  determined to do you a favour, then things going wrong, causing you a lot of trouble. In spite of this, social conventions required you to still express gratitude. What a mouthful! Yet the Japanese have a simple concise term that says it all in just 2 words, arigata-meiwaku.

The feeling of excitement you get when you first meet someone and know that you will eventually fall in love with them and are hopeful about being more than just friends. This is a more realistic version of ‘love at first sight’. Koi no yokan comes from 恋 (koi) is romantic love, and 予感 (yokan) roughly translates to ‘premonition’ or ‘hunch’, and roughly translates to ‘premonition of love’.

Pronounced [ky-oh-ee-kuu-mama], Kyōiku mama is an offensive Japanese term used to describe a mother who relentlessly pushes her children to achieve academic excellence. It literally translates to ‘education mother’.

Nekama refers to a certain type of male, who in their normal daily life are usually heterosexual, however, online they represent themselves as female. Thus, this term commonly refers to a man pretending to be a woman on the internet, regardless of his sexuality.

A Japanese philosophy that states that if something is meant to be and cannot be controlled, then why worry about it? The idea is that worrying won’t prevent the bad things from happening; it will only deprive you of the joy of enjoying the good things in life. Translated literally, shouganai means ‘it can’t be helped’.

How many times have you bought a book but never read it? This is called tsundoku, a beautiful word used to describe the act of buying books but letting them pile without ever reading them. The term originated in the Meiji era (1868–1912) as Japanese slang. The word consists of tsunde-oku (積んでおく, to pile things up ready for later and leave) and dokusho (読書, reading books). It is also used to refer to books ready for reading later when they are on a bookshelf.

Used to convey the stress-induced while speaking a foreign language, the literal meaning is ‘a meal eaten sideways’. Need help learning a language? Check out my guide to the best language learning resources here.

Yūgen is an important concept in traditional Japanese aesthetics. It refers to the sad beauty associated with human suffering, coupled with a sense of profound mysterious sense and beauty of the universe.
Manja is a person who shows so much outward love and affection towards someone they care about, like a spouse, partner, or child, to the point where they are pampering or spoiling them
The time it takes to eat a banana. Which apparently, is roughly two minutes.
To have one leg shorter than the other.
The indescribable euphoria you feel when you start to fall in love with someone.
Continuously borrowing items  from a neighbour’s house and not returning them, thereby gradually stealing everything from them one-by-one until there is nothing left.
Pronounced [zhaang-zhaah-gh], it’s the uncontrollable chattering of teeth, either due to the cold, or from intense rage.
A contract between parents and children, guaranteeing lifetime care in exchange for real estate.
Formacja is used in colloquial speech to describe a state of mind that is widespread across a particular generation or period of time. The closest English word would be ‘zeitgeist’.
Telegraphists who were part of the resistance movements on the Soviet side of the Iron Curtain.
The act of tenderly running your fingers through someone’s hair in a loving way.
Pronounced [ha-ahn-yoh-kuu], this Rukwangali word spoken by Namibians, refers to the act of tiptoeing across warm or hot sand.
The falling of leaves.
Someone that only has one love in their life or is only capable of a single person at a time.

Pochemuchka is a person, usually a child, who asks too many questions. Pronounced [POH-chay-MOO-chka[, it comes from the Russian word pocemu [POH-chay-MUH], which means ‘Why?.’ Pochemuchka was first used in a popular Soviet-era children’s book whose boy hero was given the nickname Alyosha Pochemuchka because he was never satisfied with the answers he got. Pochemuchka is a light-hearted put-down that might be expressed in English with a warning like ‘curiosity killed the cat’.
Toska is the feeling of anguish, sadness, or melancholia, even though there’s no specific cause. Often spiritual in nature, this is a deep sadness that touches the soul.
Zapoi describes being drunk for several days and waking up in an unexpected place that you don’t recognize.
Pronounced [fah-mih-tee], faamiti is a high-pitched noise made by sucking air through tightly-sealed lips in order to attract the attention of a pet or children.
This Scottish Gaelic term describes the tingle of anticipation felt in the upper lip before drinking whisky.

Pronounced [swilk], this Scottish word means to make an abnormal amount of noise whilst such as to swallow, gulp, or suck with a slobbering noise. Suilk is now used in English and even has English verb conjugations, ‘suilking‘ is the act, and a ‘suilker‘ is one who suilks.
The moment where you hesitate when introducing someone because you’ve just forgotten their name. You’ve just tartled, so you say, ‘Pardon my tartle!’
To shelter from the rain, either literally or metaphorically, such as when you’re in a bad mood and you’re waiting for the negative emotions to pass.
This single word means ‘the day before yesterday’. Anteayer is made up of the Spanish word ante, meaning before or in front of, and ayer, meaning yesterday. In some parts of Latin America

Chingada is a vulgar term commonly used in colloquial Mexican Spanish that shouldn’t be thrown around lightly. It can either refer to a special kind of hellish place that’s far away, where you send anyone who irritates you, like when you say ‘go to Hell’, or can be used as a variation of the f-word. Chingada stems from the verb chingar which means to ruin, annihilate, screw or f**k. Like I said, be careful how you use it, if at all!

While the Spanish are known for their siestas, they also have a word which means the complete opposite. Desvelado literally means ‘awake’ and comes from the verb desvelar, which means ‘to reveal’ or ‘to keep awake’. It can also be translated into English as being wide awake, unable to sleep, or sleepless.
The aftermath of seeing a sudden bright flash of light, often associated with seeing spots. Encandilar comes from the Spanish verb encandilarse, meaning ‘to be dazzled/blinded by’.
Estrenar means ‘first time’ or the beginning of something. It’s used to describe the first time you do, wear or use something for the first time. Don’t you just love that feeling?
Friolero describes a person who is particularly susceptible and sensitive to cold weather, prone to easily feeling cold. A similar term also exists in Italian, freddoloso.
The term madrugada is both Spanish and Portuguese and means to get up early in the morning at twilight – the time between midnight and the crack of dawn.

Ajeno/a generally means ‘someone else’s’ or ‘other people’s’. Literally, meaning ‘sorry for others’, pena ajena is the feeling of humiliation or embarrassment you get upon watching another person’s embarrassment. It’s so embarrassing that it makes you cringe.
A one-eyed man, blind in one eye .

To speak to someone you know well (usually friends and family) informally by addressing using the ‘tú‘ form instead of the more formal ‘usted‘. The term tutoyer is used in French to describe the same thing where the speaker uses the informal second-person pronoun tu rather than the formal vous.
A person who feels somewhat hesitant or doesn’t like to swim in an open body of water due to its low temperature.

Mångata refers to a long, wavy, road-like reflection of the moon that often appears on water. It draws its origin from ‘måne‘ meaning moon, and ‘gata‘ meaning street or road. So, mångata literally means ‘moon road’.

When two cups of coffee isn’t enough, you go for a second refill or ‘threefill’ of coffee. In Swedish, ‘tår’ means a cup of coffee and ‘patår’ is the refill of said coffee. A ‘tretår’ is therefore a second refill, or a threefill.

Gigil is the overwhelming feeling that comes over you when you see something unbearably cute that you want to squeeze or pinch it. Kind of like when your grandma wanted to pinch your cheeks when you were a child.

In Filipino culture, tampó is when a person withdraws his or her affection or cheerfulness towards someone who has hurt them. A mild case of ‘to hold a grudge’ where you’re someone between hurt and disappointed.  It usually occurs between people related to each other. For example, when a husband forgets to bring his wife flowers for their anniversary, she can have ‘tampó‘ against him.
An exaggerated, fake anger that usually follows a quarrel between lovers.
Pronounced [ee-lun-ga], this is a person who is ready to forgive someone once, tolerate it a second time, but never a third time. Kind of like, three strikes and you’re out!
The mark left on the skin from wearing something tight, such as jeans, socks, or a bra.

This Urdu word refers to a feeling of wonder and disbelief that accompanies a particularly realistic fantasy. The suspension of disbelief makes it seem so real that it temporarily becomes reality. This is usually associated with good storytelling.

The word mamihlapinatapai (sometimes also spelled mamihlapinatapei) comes from the Yaghan language of Tierra del Fuego in Southern Argentina. Mamihlapinatapai is listed in the Guinness Book of World Records as the ‘most succinct word’ and is considered extremely difficult to translate. Mamihlapinatapai is a meaningful, but wordless exchange between two people, who both desire to initiate something but are hesitant to act on it. It also can refer to a private but non-verbal exchange shared by two people, one where each knows that the other understands and agrees what is being expressed.
A chronically unlucky, usually inept, clumsy person.
Literally, ‘staircase words’, trepverter is a witty comeback you think of only after it’s too late.

Luftmensch is used to refer a person with their head in the clouds. They are more concerned with airy intellectual pursuits than practical matters like earning an income. From the Yiddish לופֿט‎ (luft, ‘air’) and מענטש‎ (mentsh, ‘man’).
the time it takes to eat a banana or the Portuguese cafuné
